paragraphs.zh-tw: You know, one of the intense pleasures of travel and one of the delights of ethnographic research is the opportunity to live amongst those who have not forgotten the old ways, who still feel their past in the wind, touch it in stones polished by rain, taste it in the bitter leaves of plants. Just to know that Jaguar shamans still journey beyond the Milky Way, or the myths of the Inuit elders still resonate with meaning, or that in the Himalaya, the Buddhists still pursue the breath of the Dharma, is to really remember the central revelation of anthropology, and that is the idea that the world in which we live does not exist in some absolute sense, but is just one model of reality, the consequence of one particular set of adaptive choices that our lineage made, albeit successfully, many generations ago.
paragraphs.en: 對我來說 在世界各地旅行 和從事人類學研究的生涯中 最大的樂趣莫過於去體驗 那些沒有忘記傳統的族群的生活 不管是沐浴在微風中 還是觸摸被雨水刷亮的石頭 或是嘗著苦葉的味道 你都能感受到他們的歷史 聽著黑豹巫師(Jaguar shamans)依然在銀河外旅行的故事 紐特(Inuit)老人的神話仍然引起後人的共鳴 而在喜馬拉雅山 佛教徒還在追隨法門 這讓我們想起人類學的核心揭示 它的意思是 我們生活的世界 不是存在於絕對的主張之中 而是客觀的現實 它是一連串適應性的選擇的結果 許多世代前 人類祖先成功地做了選擇

paragraphs.zh-tw: And of course, we all share the same adaptive imperatives. We're all born. We all bring our children into the world.
paragraphs.en: 當然 我們都遵守著相同的適應性規則 我們都生於母腹 也這樣生兒育女

paragraphs.zh-tw: We go through initiation rites. We have to deal with the inexorable separation of death, so it shouldn't surprise us that we all sing, we all dance, we all have art.
paragraphs.en: 我們要經歷成年禮的洗禮 必須面對殘酷的生離死別 所以我們會唱歌和跳舞 還創造了藝術 來排遣生命苦楚

paragraphs.zh-tw: But what's interesting is the unique cadence of the song, the rhythm of the dance in every culture. And whether it is the Penan in the forests of Borneo, or the Voodoo acolytes in Haiti, or the warriors in the Kaisut desert of Northern Kenya, the Curandero in the mountains of the Andes, or a caravanserai in the middle of the Sahara -- this is incidentally the fellow that I traveled into the desert with a month ago -- or indeed a yak herder in the slopes of Qomolangma, Everest, the goddess mother of the world.
paragraphs.en: 但有趣的是 每種文化的歌曲韻律 和舞蹈節奏都有獨一無二的特色 無論是生活在婆羅(Borneo)叢林的伯南(Penan)人 還是海地的巫毒教(Voodoo)侍僧 抑或是北肯亞(Kenya)凱蘇特(Kaisut)沙漠的武士 安迪斯(Andes)山區的巫醫(Curandero) 或撒哈拉沙漠中的圍帳客棧 我碰巧與一位犛牛牧養人結伴進沙漠 一個月前 他在珠穆朗瑪峰的山坡上牧牛 埃佛勒斯峰 世界的母親

paragraphs.zh-tw: All of these peoples teach us that there are other ways of being, other ways of thinking, other ways of orienting yourself in the Earth. And this is an idea, if you think about it, can only fill you with hope.
paragraphs.en: 這些族群展示了不同的生存方式和 不同的思維方式 以及不同的人生觀 如果你認真想想 你就會發現 它們能讓你滿懷希望

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now, together the myriad cultures of the world make up a web of spiritual life and cultural life that envelops the planet, and is as important to the well-being of the planet as indeed is the biological web of life that you know as a biosphere. And you might think of this cultural web of life as being an ethnosphere, and you might define the ethnosphere as being the sum total of all thoughts and dreams, myths, ideas, inspirations, intuitions brought into being by the human imagination since the dawn of consciousness.
paragraphs.en: 這個世界五彩繽紛的文化 猶如一張由精神生活和文化生活交織而成的網 覆蓋住整個地球 就如同地球上生態圈的網絡 對芸芸眾生是一樣重要 你可以把這種生命文化之網 看作是一個種族文化圈 這個種族文化圈可以被定義為 從人類有意識以來 通過想像力 所有的思想和夢想、神話、 想法、感動與直覺的總集合

paragraphs.zh-tw: The ethnosphere is humanity's great legacy. It's the symbol of all that we are and all that we can be as an astonishingly inquisitive species.
paragraphs.en: 種族文化圈是人類的偉大遺產 它是我們的身份標誌 也是我們人類天性格物致知的證明

paragraphs.zh-tw: And just as the biosphere has been severely eroded, so too is the ethnosphere -- and, if anything, at a far greater rate. No biologists, for example, would dare suggest that 50 percent of all species or more have been or are on the brink of extinction because it simply is not true, and yet that -- the most apocalyptic scenario in the realm of biological diversity -- scarcely approaches what we know to be the most optimistic scenario in the realm of cultural diversity.
paragraphs.en: 如同生物圈受到嚴重的侵蝕一樣 種族文化圈也面臨著同樣的厄運 而且 它的毀滅速度更快 沒有任何一位生物學家敢斷言 50% 或更多的物種已經滅絕 或者頻臨絕種 這本來就不是真的 然而對 生物多樣性 的 最悲觀的預測 還遠優於我們對 文化多樣性 的 最樂觀的預測

paragraphs.zh-tw: And the great indicator of that, of course, is language loss. When each of you in this room were born, there were 6,000 languages spoken on the planet.
paragraphs.en: 而其中最明顯的 就是語言的失傳 數十年前 當我們才出生時 地球上原本有 6000 種語言

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now, a language is not just a body of vocabulary or a set of grammatical rules. A language is a flash of the human spirit.
paragraphs.en: 語言不僅僅是字彙集合 或者文法而已 語言是人類靈魂的神來一筆

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's a vehicle through which the soul of each particular culture comes into the material world. Every language is an old-growth forest of the mind, a watershed, a thought, an ecosystem of spiritual possibilities.
paragraphs.en: 是透過它 每個獨特文化的精神 才得以在物質世界體現 每種語言都是一座古老的思想森林 也是一種意識和生命可能性的生態系

paragraphs.zh-tw: And of those 6,000 languages, as we sit here today in Monterey, fully half are no longer being whispered into the ears of children. They're no longer being taught to babies, which means, effectively, unless something changes, they're already dead.
paragraphs.en: 6000 種語言 這和今天的觀眾一樣多 其中一半已經不再向孩子們傳授 這些語言已經沒有傳人 也就是說 除非採取有效的措施 否則它們會徹底地消失

paragraphs.zh-tw: What could be more lonely than to be enveloped in silence, to be the last of your people to speak your language, to have no way to pass on the wisdom of the ancestors or anticipate the promise of the children? And yet, that dreadful fate is indeed the plight of somebody somewhere on Earth roughly every two weeks, because every two weeks, some elder dies and carries with him into the grave the last syllables of an ancient tongue. And I know there's some of you who say, "Well, wouldn't it be better, wouldn't the world be a better place if we all just spoke one language?" And I say, "Great, let's make that language Yoruba. Let's make it Cantonese.
paragraphs.en: 試想有口難言 這樣地孤單寂寞 或者 你成了最後一個會說這語言的人 祖先的智慧再也不能傳承下去 再也無法期待孩子們的承諾 另一個可怕的事實是 現在每兩個星期 就會有一位長者去世 跟著一起埋葬入土的是 一種古老語言的消逝 我知道你們有人會說 「如果世界上只有一種語言， 那不是更好嗎？」 我會說「好, 就讓約魯巴語(Yoruba) 或者是粵語(Cantonese)

paragraphs.zh-tw: Let's make it Kogi." And you'll suddenly discover what it would be like to be unable to speak your own language. And so, what I'd like to do with you today is sort of take you on a journey through the ethnosphere, a brief journey through the ethnosphere, to try to begin to give you a sense of what in fact is being lost.
paragraphs.en: 或者是科基語(Kogi) 成為那唯一的語言。」 你就會發現不能說母語 是什麼樣的感覺了 因此 今天我想做的 就是帶你們去看看這個種族文化圈 一段簡潔的種族文化圈之旅 去切身感受那消失中的文明

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now, there are many of us who sort of forget that when I say "different ways of being," I really do mean different ways of being. Take, for example, this child of a Barasana in the Northwest Amazon, the people of the anaconda who believe that mythologically they came up the milk river from the east in the belly of sacred snakes.
paragraphs.en: 可能你們有些人會忘記了 我在前面說過“不同的生存方式” 那是真的 完全不同的生命之道 舉個例子 這個小孩生活在亞瑪遜西北部的巴拉撒拉地區 他們被稱為森蚺之族 他們相信 他們是來自銀河東岸 誕生於神聖的蛇腹

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now, this is a people who cognitively do not distinguish the color blue from the color green because the canopy of the heavens is equated to the canopy of the forest upon which the people depend. They have a curious language and marriage rule which is called "linguistic exogamy:" you must marry someone who speaks a different language.
paragraphs.en: 這個族群的人在意識上 認為藍色和綠色是相同的顏色 因為天堂的藍色穹頂 與他們安身其下的綠色樹冠 是完全相同的意義 他們有特別的 "與異種語言通婚" 規則 這被稱為語言學異族通婚 你必須與一個說不同語言的人結婚

paragraphs.zh-tw: And this is all rooted in the mythological past, yet the curious thing is in these long houses, where there are six or seven languages spoken because of intermarriage, you never hear anyone practicing a language. They simply listen and then begin to speak.
paragraphs.en: 這都是根據神話傳說的歷史傳承下來的 你可以看到一個奇怪的現象 由於異語言同婚的緣故 一個大家族會有六七種語言 你從不會看到有人在練習別種語言 他們只要聽 就會說了

paragraphs.zh-tw: Or, one of the most fascinating tribes I ever lived with, the Waorani of northeastern Ecuador, an astonishing people first contacted peacefully in 1958. In 1957, five missionaries attempted contact and made a critical mistake.
paragraphs.en: 其中一個我共同生活過的奇妙種族 厄瓜多東北部的華拉尼(Waorani)族人 早在 1958 年 就與現代人有和平的接觸 1957年 有五名傳教士試圖接近他們 但是這些人犯了一個致命的錯誤

paragraphs.zh-tw: They dropped from the air 8 x 10 glossy photographs of themselves in what we would say to be friendly gestures, forgetting that these people of the rainforest had never seen anything two-dimensional in their lives. They picked up these photographs from the forest floor, tried to look behind the face to find the form or the figure, found nothing, and concluded that these were calling cards from the devil, so they speared the five missionaries to death.
paragraphs.en: 他們從空中丟下 八到十張他們自己的照片 在我們看來 這是友好的表示 卻忘了這些生活在雨林中的人 從來沒有見過平面圖像 他們從林地上撿起這些照片 試圖從相片背面 找到這些人的真實形體 但什麼也沒發現 所以他們認為 這是惡魔的召喚卡 於是他們用長矛戮死了這五名傳教士

paragraphs.zh-tw: But the Waorani didn't just spear outsiders. They speared each other.
paragraphs.en: 但華拉尼不僅戮死外來者 他們還自相殘殺

paragraphs.zh-tw: 54 percent of their mortality was due to them spearing each other. We traced genealogies back eight generations, and we found two instances of natural death and when we pressured the people a little bit about it, they admitted that one of the fellows had gotten so old that he died getting old, so we speared him anyway.
paragraphs.en: 54% 的死亡人口是被他們自己的族人戮死的 我們對一個八代宗譜進行調查 發現只有兩例自然死亡 當我們追根究柢 他們終於承認 當族人因為年邁難免一死 我們就乾脆戮死他 為他送終

paragraphs.zh-tw: But at the same time they had a perspicacious knowledge of the forest that was astonishing. Their hunters could smell animal urine at 40 paces and tell you what species left it behind.
paragraphs.en: 另一方面 他們對叢林 有著令人驚詫的洞察力 獵人們能聞到 40 步外的動物尿液 再告訴你是什麼動物留下的

paragraphs.zh-tw: In the early '80s, I had a really astonishing assignment when I was asked by my professor at Harvard if I was interested in going down to Haiti, infiltrating the secret societies which were the foundation of Duvalier's strength and Tonton Macoutes, and securing the poison used to make zombies. In order to make sense out of sensation, of course, I had to understand something about this remarkable faith of Vodoun. And Voodoo is not a black magic cult.
paragraphs.en: 80 年代早期 我曾有一項奇妙的任務 我在哈佛大學的教授問我 是否有興趣去海地 去潛入一個秘密社團 那是海地總統杜華利和他的政權 支持者的基地 並且帶回一種製造僵屍的毒藥 為了理解其中的奧秘 我必須先瞭解這神奇的巫毒教信仰 其實它不是什麼邪教組織

paragraphs.zh-tw: On the contrary, it's a complex metaphysical worldview. It's interesting.
paragraphs.en: 相反地 它是一個複雜且抽象的世界觀 這是很有意思的

paragraphs.zh-tw: If I asked you to name the great religions of the world, what would you say? Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, Judaism, whatever. There's always one continent left out, the assumption being that sub-Saharan Africa had no religious beliefs. Well, of course, they did and Voodoo is simply the distillation of these very profound religious ideas that came over during the tragic Diaspora of the slavery era.
paragraphs.en: 如果要列舉世界上的重要宗教 你會舉出哪些例子 基督教 伊斯蘭教 佛教 猶太教... 大概這些吧 但有一個大陸總是被遺忘 很多人認為 撒哈拉以南的非洲地區 沒有宗教信仰 當然 這是不正確的 巫毒教常被認為不過是 在奴隸時代悲哀的種族遷徙下 所跟隨來的偉大宗教奧義的副產品

paragraphs.zh-tw: But, what makes Voodoo so interesting is that it's this living relationship between the living and the dead. So, the living give birth to the spirits.
paragraphs.en: 但是 巫毒的獨特之處在於 它是生者與死者之間 一種實在的聯繫 生者孕育了靈魂

paragraphs.zh-tw: The spirits can be invoked from beneath the Great Water, responding to the rhythm of the dance to momentarily displace the soul of the living, so that for that brief shining moment, the acolyte becomes the god. That's why the Voodooists like to say that "You white people go to church and speak about God.
paragraphs.en: 應著舞蹈的節奏翩翩起舞 可以喚醒大水之下的靈魂 暫時地代替生者的靈魂 在那個短暫的閃光時刻 侍僧會成為神 因此 巫毒教徒喜歡說: 「你們這些白人去教堂做禮拜 談論上帝,

paragraphs.zh-tw: We dance in the temple and become God." And because you are possessed, you are taken by the spirit -- how can you be harmed? So you see these astonishing demonstrations: Voodoo acolytes in a state of trance handling burning embers with impunity, a rather astonishing demonstration of the ability of the mind to affect the body that bears it when catalyzed in the state of extreme excitation. Now, of all the peoples that I've ever been with, the most extraordinary are the Kogi of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta in northern Colombia.
paragraphs.en: 而我們就在聖殿起舞 成為上帝。」 因為你已經被神靈附體 那你又怎會受到傷害呢 於是 你會看到一些令人驚奇的現象 巫毒教侍僧進入神志恍惚的狀態 手持燃燒的枝條 但卻毫髮無損 當他們進入變得極端亢奮時 你看到的現象更加令人吃驚 那是人類意志力的強大證明 在我接觸過的所有族群中 最不平凡的 是生活在哥倫比亞北部的聖馬爾塔山區的科基人

paragraphs.zh-tw: Descendants of the ancient Tairona civilization which once carpeted the Caribbean coastal plain of Colombia, in the wake of the conquest, these people retreated into an isolated volcanic massif that soars above the Caribbean coastal plain. In a bloodstained continent, these people alone were never conquered by the Spanish.
paragraphs.en: 這個種族是古代泰榮納(Tairona)文明的後裔 他們一度征服了哥倫比亞的加勒比海岸平原地區 列強的號角響起 此後 他們避退到加勒比海岸平原的 一個與世隔絕的火山山區 在這個血腥肆虐的大陸 這個種族逃過西班牙人的荼毒

paragraphs.zh-tw: To this day, they remain ruled by a ritual priesthood but the training for the priesthood is rather extraordinary. The young acolytes are taken away from their families at the age of three and four, sequestered in a shadowy world of darkness in stone huts at the base of glaciers for 18 years: two nine-year periods deliberately chosen to mimic the nine months of gestation they spend in their natural mother's womb; now they are metaphorically in the womb of the great mother.
paragraphs.en: 至到今天 他們仍然沿用僧侶會統治制度 但是 他們的僧侶訓練方式非常獨特 年幼的侍僧在三四歲時 就被帶離他們的家庭 隱居在黑暗世界 在冰川上用石頭小屋待滿十八年 兩個九年的總和 它象徵在母腹的 九月懷胎 在此期間

paragraphs.zh-tw: And for this entire time, they are inculturated into the values of their society, values that maintain the proposition that their prayers and their prayers alone maintain the cosmic -- or we might say the ecological -- balance. And at the end of this amazing initiation, one day they're suddenly taken out and for the first time in their lives, at the age of 18, they see a sunrise. And in that crystal moment of awareness of first light as the Sun begins to bathe the slopes of the stunningly beautiful landscape, suddenly everything they have learned in the abstract is affirmed in stunning glory. And the priest steps back and says, "You see? It's really as I've told you.
paragraphs.en: 他們如同重新回到母腹中 被族群文化的價值觀所滋養著 這些價值觀維繫著 信徒與宇宙之間的關係 我們可稱之為生態平衡 十八年後 一天他們突然被帶出來 他們生平第一次走出小屋看到陽光 大地在陽光的照耀下 呈現出令人震撼的壯觀美景 那一刻 意識突然蘇醒 他們以前學到的所有抽象知識 都在令人驚歎的榮耀中得到印證 這時祭司說: 「看到了吧 我以前教你的都是真的

paragraphs.zh-tw: It is that beautiful. It is yours to protect." They call themselves the "elder brothers" and they say we, who are the younger brothers, are the ones responsible for destroying the world. Now, this level of intuition becomes very important.
paragraphs.en: 這裏是多麼的美麗 你要保護它。」 他們稱自己為兄長 稱現代人為弟兄 說我們是破壞世界的人 現在 這種程度的感情是非常重要的

paragraphs.zh-tw: Whenever we think of indigenous people and landscape, we either invoke Rousseau and the old canard of the "noble savage," which is an idea racist in its simplicity, or alternatively, we invoke Thoreau and say these people are closer to the Earth than we are. Well, indigenous people are neither sentimental nor weakened by nostalgia.
paragraphs.en: 說到土著和原始的風土人情 我們會想到羅素 關於那高貴野人的古老誑語 只是被簡化的種族歧視 或者我們會想到梭羅 他說這些人比我們更親近大地 這些在地族群並不多愁善感 也不會沉溺往日時光

paragraphs.zh-tw: There's not a lot of room for either in the malarial swamps of the Asmat or in the chilling winds of Tibet, but they have, nevertheless, through time and ritual, forged a traditional mystique of the Earth that is based not on the idea of being self-consciously close to it, but on a far subtler intuition: the idea that the Earth itself can only exist because it is breathed into being by human consciousness. Now, what does that mean? It means that a young kid from the Andes who's raised to believe that that mountain is an Apu spirit that will direct his or her destiny will be a profoundly different human being and have a different relationship to that resource or that place than a young kid from Montana raised to believe that a mountain is a pile of rock ready to be mined.
paragraphs.en: 在瘧疾盛行的阿斯瑪特(Asmant)濕地 在寒風刺骨的西藏 並沒有多少空間 但是他們經年累月地 不間斷地演示 而創造了流傳百世的奇跡 這並不是因為他們自覺地認識到這一點 而是憑著非常細微的靈感 他們認為這個地球本身的存在 是因為人類透過意識吸收了自然的精華 那麼 這是什麼意思呢 比如一位生活在安第斯山脈的小孩 從小就被教導說 那裏的大山是阿普神的化身 它將會指引他們的命運 他們是一類完全不同的人 與自然環境有一種不同的連結 而對蒙大拿州的年輕人 一座大山只不過是一堆大石頭 可以用來開採石礦

paragraphs.zh-tw: Whether it's the abode of a spirit or a pile of ore is irrelevant. What's interesting is the metaphor that defines the relationship between the individual and the natural world.
paragraphs.en: 無論那是神的住所 或是一堆礦石 這都不重要 重點是 他們的所教育的文化 定義了人與自然之間的關係

paragraphs.zh-tw: I was raised in the forests of British Columbia to believe those forests existed to be cut. That made me a different human being than my friends amongst the Kwagiulth who believe that those forests were the abode of Huxwhukw and the Crooked Beak of Heaven and the cannibal spirits that dwelled at the north end of the world, spirits they would have to engage during their Hamatsa initiation.
paragraphs.en: 我在英國哥倫比亞的叢林長大 我學到叢林是生來被砍伐的 這種想法讓我與誇基特爾(Kwakiutl)部落的朋友們 成為截然不同的人 他們相信 這些樹木是胡克神(Hukuk) 和天堂之眼的化身 吃人的精靈在世界的最北邊 在哈馬撒(Hamatsa)成人禮上 他們會與這些精靈戰鬥

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now, if you begin to look at the idea that these cultures could create different realities, you could begin to understand some of their extraordinary discoveries. Take this plant here. It's a photograph I took in the Northwest Amazon just last April.
paragraphs.en: 如果你開始去了解 這些文化能創造不同的生活方式 你就會開始認識到 他們與眾不同的生活方式 這張照片是去年八月在亞馬遜西北地方拍的

paragraphs.zh-tw: This is ayahuasca, which many of you have heard about, the most powerful psychoactive preparation of the shaman's repertoire. What makes ayahuasca fascinating is not the sheer pharmacological potential of this preparation, but the elaboration of it. It's made really of two different sources: on the one hand, this woody liana which has in it a series of beta-carbolines, harmine, harmaline, mildly hallucinogenic -- to take the vine alone is rather to have sort of blue hazy smoke drift across your consciousness -- but it's mixed with the leaves of a shrub in the coffee family called Psychotria viridis.
paragraphs.en: 這是阿亞胡斯卡(ayahuasca)藤 俗稱死藤 一種非常強效的精神麻醉植物 薩滿教徒用它製作迷幻藥- 死藤水 死藤水的奇妙之處 不在於它神奇的藥用性 它其實是由兩種不同的物質組成的 一方面 它是一種藤本植物 含有 β-哢啉 蓬鹼 和微量的致幻成份 食用它的藤 就彷彿看到你的意識 被一層藍色煙霧籠罩 它與九節木的咖啡屬灌木的枝葉 混雜在一起

paragraphs.zh-tw: This plant had in it some very powerful tryptamines, very close to brain serotonin, dimethyltryptamine, 5-methoxydimethyltryptamine. If you've ever seen the Yanomami blowing that snuff up their noses, that substance they make from a different set of species also contains methoxydimethyltryptamine.
paragraphs.en: 這種植物具有一種強效的色胺 它的成分與腦內的5-羥色胺的成份 非常接近 亞諾馬米(Yanomami)部落的人 也會從含有5-羥色胺的植物中 提取這種物質 並且用鼻子吸食

paragraphs.zh-tw: To have that powder blown up your nose is rather like being shot out of a rifle barrel lined with baroque paintings and landing on a sea of electricity. It doesn't create the distortion of reality; it creates the dissolution of reality.
paragraphs.en: 如果你用鼻吸入這些粉末 你會感覺像被砲管射出 然後跟一排巴洛克畫像 一起掉落到整池的電流裡 現實沒有被扭曲 它只是消失

paragraphs.zh-tw: In fact, I used to argue with my professor, Richard Evan Shultes -- who is a man who sparked the psychedelic era with his discovery of the magic mushrooms in Mexico in the 1930s -- I used to argue that you couldn't classify these tryptamines as hallucinogenic because by the time you're under the effects there's no one home anymore to experience a hallucination. But the thing about tryptamines is they cannot be taken orally because they're denatured by an enzyme found naturally in the human gut called monoamine oxidase.
paragraphs.en: 事實上 我曾與我的導師 Richard Evan Shultes 爭論過 他曾揚名於1960的迷幻藥年代 因為他在1930年代所發現的 一種墨西哥的神奇蘑菇 我和他爭論說 你不能把這些色胺歸入 迷幻成份類別 因為當它們發揮效力時 你已迷幻到不知迷幻為何物 但是 這些色胺物質並不能用吃的 因為它們會被 人體器官中的單胺氧化酶(MAO)的酶改變活性

paragraphs.zh-tw: They can only be taken orally if taken in conjunction with some other chemical that denatures the MAO. Now, the fascinating things are that the beta-carbolines found within that liana are MAO inhibitors of the precise sort necessary to potentiate the tryptamine. So you ask yourself a question.
paragraphs.en: 要口服這些色胺物質 還必須吃下改變單胺氧化酶(MAO)活性的其他化學物質 有意思的是 這種藤本植物中存在的 β-哢啉 正好能夠抑制單胺氧化酶(MAO) 同時發揮色胺的效力 因此 問問自己

paragraphs.zh-tw: How, in a flora of 80,000 species of vascular plants, do these people find these two morphologically unrelated plants that when combined in this way, created a kind of biochemical version of the whole being greater than the sum of the parts? Well, we use that great euphemism, "trial and error," which is exposed to be meaningless. But you ask the Indians, and they say, "The plants talk to us." Well, what does that mean? This tribe, the Cofan, has 17 varieties of ayahuasca, all of which they distinguish a great distance in the forest, all of which are referable to our eye as one species.
paragraphs.en: 在這片叢林中 有 8000 種藤蔓植物 他們是如何發現這兩種完全不同的植物 能這樣組合在一起 這如同一種生化實驗 多種成分混合的效應會大於各單獨成分 我們都相信失敗是成功之母 但這樣實驗下去總是徒勞 不過 印第安人會說 "是植物告訴我們的" 那是什麼意思呢? 科凡(Cofan)部落的人發現了 17 種死藤 全部是他們在叢林深處發現的 在我們看來 它們是不同的物種

paragraphs.zh-tw: And then you ask them how they establish their taxonomy and they say, "I thought you knew something about plants. I mean, don't you know anything?" And I said, "No." Well, it turns out you take each of the 17 varieties in the night of a full moon, and it sings to you in a different key.
paragraphs.en: 如果你問他們是如何給這些植物分門別類的 他們就會說:「我想你對植物有一些研究， 應該對植物有一定的瞭解吧? 」 我說:「我不懂。」 他說這十七種植物 在月圓時 它們會用不同的音高對你歌唱

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now, that's not going to get you a Ph.D. at Harvard, but it's a lot more interesting than counting stamens. Now -- -- the problem -- the problem is that even those of us sympathetic with the plight of indigenous people view them as quaint and colorful but somehow reduced to the margins of history as the real world, meaning our world, moves on.
paragraphs.en: 這個發現不會讓你得到哈佛的博士學位 這可比計算雄蕊數目好玩多了 現在 （鼓掌） 我們面臨這樣一個問題 雖然我們會同情土著人的遭遇 認為他們生活多彩且不被打擾 但是隨著我們的世界向前發展 這些人被排擠到歷史的邊緣

paragraphs.zh-tw: Well, the truth is the 20th century, 300 years from now, is not going to be remembered for its wars or its technological innovations, but rather as the era in which we stood by and either actively endorsed or passively accepted the massive destruction of both biological and cultural diversity on the planet. Now, the problem isn't change. All cultures through all time have constantly been engaged in a dance with new possibilities of life.
paragraphs.en: 20 世紀 以及接下來的 300 年 戰爭會被遺忘 科技發展也隨風而逝 但後人們會記住 現在的我們 積極地對地球上的生態和文化多樣性 進行大規模的破壞 或者姑息這個局面 我們不能怪罪世界生活的進步 所有的文化也全都 一直受到新的生活方式 的強烈衝擊

paragraphs.zh-tw: And the problem is not technology itself. The Sioux Indians did not stop being Sioux when they gave up the bow and arrow any more than an American stopped being an American when he gave up the horse and buggy.
paragraphs.en: 也不能怪罪科技的日新月異 蘇族印第安人即使放下弓箭 他們依然是蘇族印第安人 當美國人不再騎馬和坐馬車時 他們仍然是美國人

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's not change or technology that threatens the integrity of the ethnosphere. It is power, the crude face of domination. Wherever you look around the world, you discover that these are not cultures destined to fade away; these are dynamic living peoples being driven out of existence by identifiable forces that are beyond their capacity to adapt to: whether it's the egregious deforestation in the homeland of the Penan -- a nomadic people from Southeast Asia, from Sarawak -- a people who lived free in the forest until a generation ago, and now have all been reduced to servitude and prostitution on the banks of the rivers, where you can see the river itself is soiled with the silt that seems to be carrying half of Borneo away to the South China Sea, where the Japanese freighters hang light in the horizon ready to fill their holds with raw logs ripped from the forest -- or, in the case of the Yanomami, it's the disease entities that have come in, in the wake of the discovery of gold.
paragraphs.en: 威脅種族圈完整性的 不是新時代或新科技 而是權力 是野蠻的排他主義 去看看我們的世界 你會發現 沒有一種文化是註定要消亡的 這些富有活力的人們 霸道的力量排除了他們的存在 他們根本無從適應 無論是伯南(Penan)腹地 肆無忌憚的森林砍伐 還是東南亞的撒拉瓦克遊民部落 他們上一代還自由地生活在叢林中 現在全淪落為僕役和妓女 在婆羅洲(Borneo)溪流沿岸 河水含沙量高到像泥漿 像要把他們的一半土地都沖走 全帶進南中國海 同時日本的人貨船已經整裝待發 準備運走從婆羅洲森林砍伐的原木 我們再來看亞諾馬米部落 金礦的發現引來掏金潮 也因此帶來了病原體

paragraphs.zh-tw: Or if we go into the mountains of Tibet, where I'm doing a lot of research recently, you'll see it's a crude face of political domination. You know, genocide, the physical extinction of a people is universally condemned, but ethnocide, the destruction of people's way of life, is not only not condemned, it's universally, in many quarters, celebrated as part of a development strategy.
paragraphs.en: 我們再來看看西藏山區 最近我做了大量的研究 在那裏 你會看到政治獨裁的殘酷面 雖然種族屠殺 物裡上的滅絕一個族群 在全世界受到一致的譴責 但是種族文化滅絕 也就是抹消人們的生活方式 卻被姑息 甚至在很多地方被表揚 被視為文化發展的一部分

paragraphs.zh-tw: And you cannot understand the pain of Tibet until you move through it at the ground level. I once travelled 6,000 miles from Chengdu in Western China overland through southeastern Tibet to Lhasa with a young colleague, and it was only when I got to Lhasa that I understood the face behind the statistics you hear about: 6,000 sacred monuments torn apart to dust and ashes, 1.2 million people killed by the cadres during the Cultural Revolution.
paragraphs.en: 你無法體會西藏承受的痛楚 除非你親身去體會 我跋涉 6000 英哩 從中國成都 穿過西藏的東南邊 到達拉薩 跟著一個年輕同事 直到那時我也才真的明白 你們所聽說的那些統計數字 背後隱藏的真相 6000 座神聖的古蹟被搗毀 120 萬人被共產黨殺害 這都發生在文化大革命期間

paragraphs.zh-tw: This young man's father had been ascribed to the Panchen Lama. That meant he was instantly killed at the time of the Chinese invasion.
paragraphs.en: 年輕同事的父親被指為班禪喇嘛一派 在中國人入侵後 他父親因此被殺害了

paragraphs.zh-tw: His uncle fled with His Holiness in the Diaspora that took the people to Nepal. His mother was incarcerated for the crime of being wealthy.
paragraphs.en: 他叔叔和他的導師 跟著大逃亡潮到尼泊爾 他的母親因為富有的身家 被捕入獄

paragraphs.zh-tw: He was smuggled into the jail at the age of two to hide beneath her skirt tails because she couldn't bear to be without him. The sister who had done that brave deed was put into an education camp.
paragraphs.en: 兩歲的他被藏在裙子下 悄悄地帶進牢房 因為她不能離開她的兒子 好心協助他們的姐姐 被送去再教育

paragraphs.zh-tw: One day she inadvertently stepped on an armband of Mao, and for that transgression, she was given seven years of hard labor. The pain of Tibet can be impossible to bear, but the redemptive spirit of the people is something to behold.
paragraphs.en: 有一天 她不小心踩到印有毛主席頭像 的臂章 而被處以判國罪 被迫勞改七年之久 西藏的痛楚是讓人難以承受 但也因此見證人類的救贖精神

paragraphs.zh-tw: And in the end, then, it really comes down to a choice: do we want to live in a monochromatic world of monotony or do we want to embrace a polychromatic world of diversity? Margaret Mead, the great anthropologist, said, before she died, that her greatest fear was that as we drifted towards this blandly amorphous generic world view not only would we see the entire range of the human imagination reduced to a more narrow modality of thought, but that we would wake from a dream one day having forgotten there were even other possibilities. And it's humbling to remember that our species has, perhaps, been around for [150,000] years.
paragraphs.en: 到最後 我們將面臨這樣的一個選擇 我們是要一個單一單調的世界 還是想要一個五彩繽紛、多樣化的世界? 偉大的人類學家 Margaret Mead 在生前曾經說過 她最擔心的是 人類隨波逐流地接受 這種統一、概括的世界觀 我們不僅會看到 人類的想像力 退化得更狹隘短淺 最後我們會一覺醒來 忘記這個世界還有其他的可能性 謙卑地說 人類的[15 萬年]的歷史 不過是滄海一粟

paragraphs.zh-tw: The Neolithic Revolution -- which gave us agriculture, at which time we succumbed to the cult of the seed; the poetry of the shaman was displaced by the prose of the priesthood; we created hierarchy specialization surplus -- is only 10,000 years ago. The modern industrial world as we know it is barely 300 years old.
paragraphs.en: 新石器時代--人類農業的初始 那時我們對種子頂禮膜拜 薩滿的詩篇 被祭司的韻文取代 我們創造了層層的社會分工 不過是一萬年前的事 現代化的工業社會 也只有將近三百年的歷史

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now, that shallow history doesn't suggest to me that we have all the answers for all of the challenges that will confront us in the ensuing millennia. When these myriad cultures of the world are asked the meaning of being human, they respond with 10,000 different voices.
paragraphs.en: 在我看來 這個短暫的歷史 並不足以證明我們有能力 解決這個千禧年將面臨的各種挑戰 當我們向這個世界的多元文化 詢問生命的意義 你會得到一萬個不同的答案

paragraphs.zh-tw: And it's within that song that we will all rediscover the possibility of being what we are: a fully conscious species, fully aware of ensuring that all peoples and all gardens find a way to flourish. And there are great moments of optimism. This is a photograph I took at the northern tip of Baffin Island when I went narwhal hunting with some Inuit people, and this man, Olayuk, told me a marvelous story of his grandfather.
paragraphs.en: 在這個歌聲中 我們將會重新發現 作為人類的別種可能：一個有完全意識的物種 充分認識到 我們必須保證所有種族和生物 都是昌盛繁榮 對生活充滿樂觀的 這張照片是我在巴芬(Baffin)島的北邊山頂上拍攝的 那時 我和一些因紐特人去捕獨角鯨 這個叫奧拉雅的人 述說了他祖父的傳奇故事

paragraphs.zh-tw: The Canadian government has not always been kind to the Inuit people, and during the 1950s, to establish our sovereignty, we forced them into settlements. This old man's grandfather refused to go.
paragraphs.en: 1950 年代 加拿大政府並沒有 友善地對待因纽特人 為了確立我們國家的主權 他們被趕到指定區域 這位老人的祖父拒絕遷移

paragraphs.zh-tw: The family, fearful for his life, took away all of his weapons, all of his tools. Now, you must understand that the Inuit did not fear the cold; they took advantage of it.
paragraphs.en: 他家人擔心他的安全 拿走他所有的武器 也拿走所有工具 先告訴你們 紐特人一點都不怕冷 他們善用這個優勢

paragraphs.zh-tw: The runners of their sleds were originally made of fish wrapped in caribou hide. So, this man's grandfather was not intimidated by the Arctic night or the blizzard that was blowing.
paragraphs.en: 他們雪橇的滑刃是用凍魚乾 外面包裹馴鹿皮做成的 這位男子的祖父並不懼怕北極的夜晚 和凜冽的暴風雪

paragraphs.zh-tw: He simply slipped outside, pulled down his sealskin trousers and defecated into his hand. And as the feces began to freeze, he shaped it into the form of a blade. He put a spray of saliva on the edge of the shit knife and as it finally froze solid, he butchered a dog with it.
paragraphs.en: 他就在雪地裡 脫下海豹皮長褲 把大便拉到手上 等大便開始凍硬時 把它削成刀片的形状 然後在大便刀片的邊緣 抹上口水 等它完全結凍變硬 他再用它宰殺了一條狗

paragraphs.zh-tw: He skinned the dog and improvised a harness, took the ribcage of the dog and improvised a sled, harnessed up an adjacent dog, and disappeared over the ice floes, shit knife in belt. Talk about getting by with nothing.
paragraphs.en: 剝下狗皮 做成一副挽具 又取出狗的胸腔 造了一對雪橇 套到另一隻狗身上 拽著那把大便刀 消失在冰原上 這就是雙手萬能囉

paragraphs.zh-tw: And this, in many ways -- -- is a symbol of the resilience of the Inuit people and of all indigenous people around the world. The Canadian government in April of 1999 gave back to total control of the Inuit an area of land larger than California and Texas put together.
paragraphs.en: 從很多方面來說 （鼓掌） 這是他們頑強生命力的寫照 也是所有土著人的生命力的真實寫照 1999年4月 加拿大政府 重新歸還給因紐特人土地 這片土地比加州和德州的總和還更大

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's our new homeland. It's called Nunavut. It's an independent territory. They control all mineral resources.
paragraphs.en: 這是我們的新家園 它叫紐勒維特(Nunavut) 這是一塊獨立的領土 他們擁有所有的礦物資源

paragraphs.zh-tw: An amazing example of how a nation-state can seek restitution with its people. And finally, in the end, I think it's pretty obvious at least to all of all us who've traveled in these remote reaches of the planet, to realize that they're not remote at all.
paragraphs.en: 這個例子正好說明了 一個國家如何去修復與人民的關係 最後 我認為 至少對我們這些曾去過 一些世界上偏遠地方的人來說 其實他們一點也不"偏遠"

paragraphs.zh-tw: They're homelands of somebody. They represent branches of the human imagination that go back to the dawn of time. And for all of us, the dreams of these children, like the dreams of our own children, become part of the naked geography of hope.
paragraphs.en: 那裏也是某個族群的家 他們是遠古人類想像力的遺產 人類歷史源頭的分支 而這些孩子的夢想 與我們自己孩子的夢想一樣 是整個世界未來希望的一部分

paragraphs.zh-tw: So, what we're trying to do at the National Geographic, finally, is, we believe that politicians will never accomplish anything. We think that polemics -- -- we think that polemics are not persuasive, but we think that storytelling can change the world, and so we are probably the best storytelling institution in the world. We get 35 million hits on our website every month.
paragraphs.en: 因此 我們嘗試透過"國家地理雜誌"去告訴所有人 政治家並不能做到些什麼 我們認為 （鼓掌） 我們覺得雄辯不一定能說服人 但我們認為 說故事才能改變這個世界 因此 我們是最會說故事的機構 我們網站每月點擊量達到 3 千 5 百萬次

paragraphs.zh-tw: 156 nations carry our television channel. Our magazines are read by millions.
paragraphs.en: 我們的節目在 156 個國家播放 我們的雜誌有上百萬的讀者

paragraphs.zh-tw: And what we're doing is a series of journeys to the ethnosphere where we're going to take our audience to places of such cultural wonder that they cannot help but come away dazzled by what they have seen, and hopefully, therefore, embrace gradually, one by one, the central revelation of anthropology: that this world deserves to exist in a diverse way, that we can find a way to live in a truly multicultural, pluralistic world where all of the wisdom of all peoples can contribute to our collective well-being. Thank you very much.
paragraphs.en: 我們要做的是 通過一系列旅程 帶領我們的觀眾去體驗種族文化圈的 文化奇跡之地 他們所看到的一切 會讓他們感到震撼 而且我們希望 他們逐漸地接納 人類學的核心揭示： 這個世界需要多樣化的生存方式 讓我們能夠真正地生活在 一個多元而豐富的世界之中 讓所有種族的智慧 都能為全人類的福址做出貢獻 謝謝 （鼓掌）
